title: Current Weather Game Center Here's how to keep your pets safe during a heat wave
content: Sunny 81 84 65 Today 84 65 Tuesday 89 63 Wednesday 74 59 Latest Weathercast Now 81 Tue 89 Wed 74 The Austin Police Department is actively investigating a shooting at the North Austin Target store that left three people dead. Be prepared for a few days of hot weather, with a Heat Advisory in effect for most of western Washington through Tuesday evening. Armstrong Williams takes on the news of the week and asks the questions you want answered. Don’t miss our weekly town hall by KOMO News Staff TOPICS: SEATTLE — As summers in western Washington get hotter, veterinarians are reminding people to take extra precautions with their pets. Sidewalks can get hot. If the pavement is too hot for you to touch for 10 seconds, then it is too hot for your dog's paws. Your barefoot also serves as a good barometer. This includes asphalt and artificial grass. “In addition to damaged paws, hot pavement can also increase a dog’s body temperature and contribute to the development of heatstroke,” said Jerry Klein, the American Kennel Club's chief veterinary officer. According to the Journal of the American Medical Association, when the air temperature is 86 degrees, the asphalt temperature can register at 135 degrees. If you need to take your dog out during hot weather, avoid the hottest time of the day and walk in the early morning or evening. You should also try to walk your pets in grassy or shady areas. Don't leave your pet unattended in direct sunlight. Make sure they can go into the shade and have plenty of water. If you're leaving your pet alone inside, make sure it is cool. Keep screened windows open or a fan running and make sure they have plenty of water. Never leave animals unattended in a vehicle. Temperatures rise quickly in cars. Under Washington state law, an animal control officer or law enforcement officer has the authority to remove an animal from a vehicle by any means necessary if the animal is suffering or is likely to suffer from exposure to excessive heat and the owner may be charged with animal cruelty. Avoid overexerting your animal in hot weather. Know the symptoms of overheating in pets. According to the American Kennel Club, signs of heat stress include: They suggest taking your animal to the vet if symptoms include: Small and short-legged dogs are particularly susceptible to overheating as their bodies absorb heat closer to the hot ground. Pets with flat faces also heat up faster.

title: Pennsylvania explosion: Gov. says several explosions occurred
content: Several people appear to have been injured at a mill in Western Pennsylvania. WPXI reported that emergency crews were sent to an explosion at the U.S. Steel Clairton Coke Works. The mill is located along the Monongahela River south of Pittsburgh. Update 2:48 p.m. ET Aug. 11: Pennsylvania Gov. Josh Shapiro said that there were several explosions. He said injured employees were taken to area hospitals and that search and rescue operations continue at the site. Multiple explosions occurred today at U.S. Steel Clairton Coke Works in Clairton, PA. Since then, my Administration has... Update 1:57 p.m. ET Aug. 11: Officials with Allegheny County said two people were still unaccounted for, WPXI reported. The United Steel Workers Union District 10 Director Bernie Hall released a statement, which read: “The USW has occupational health and safety experts and other representatives on the ground at the Clairton Works assessing the situation and aiding our members,” adding, “While we are still determining the scope of the tragedy, we are aware that multiple workers are receiving medical treatment for their injuries. In the coming days, we will work with the appropriate authorities to ensure a thorough investigation and to see that our members get the support they need.” The Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco, Firearms and Explosives said it is assisting in the response. Update 1:21 p.m. ET Aug. 11: Health department advises people who are within a mile of the plant to remain inside, closing all windows and doors. They are also advising to have HVAC systems set to recirculate the air inside, and avoid using anything that could draw outside air inside, WPXI reported. “ACHD Air Quality monitors have not detected levels of PM2.5 and So2 above federal standards,” the agency said. 0 of 8 Update 12:58 p.m. ET Aug. 11: Sen. John Fetterman told reporters that the explosion “reminds everybody how dangerous of a job it is to make steel here,” The New York Times reported. Update 12:42 p.m. ET Aug. 11: Allegheny County Department of Emergency Services spokesperson Kasey Reigner said that dozens were injured in the blast. The plant is one of the largest coking operations in North America and employs several thousand people, The Associated Press reported. In June, U.S. Steel and Nippon Steel announced a partnership, a year and a half after the Japanese company proposed an almost $15 billion buyout of the company, the AP reported. This is not the first emergency the plant has experienced. In February, a battery issue led to “a buildup of combustible material” that caught fire and caused an audible “boom,” the county health department said, according to the AP. Two workers got material in their eyes and were treated at an area hospital. There have also been concerns about the environmental impacts of the plant. It was sued in 2017 for pollution, settling the lawsuit for $8.5 million in 2019. The company had agreed to spend $6.5 million to reduce soot emissions and odors produced by the plant, the AP reported. Update 12:27 p.m. ET Aug. 11: WPXI reported at least one person was killed. Update 12:14 p.m. ET Aug. 11: WPXI reported that there are people unaccounted for and that there is a search for victims who may be trapped in the rubble. Pennsylvania Gov. Josh Shapiro said that his administration is in contact with officials in Cariton and that the Pennsylvania Emergency Management Agency, along with the state police, has offered to assist. My Administration is in touch with local officials in Clairton, PA as they respond to an explosion at US Steel Clairton Coke Works plant this morning. @PEMAHQ and @PAStatePolice are in touch with first responders and have offered all assistance.The scene is still active, and… Original report: Coke, according to PACokeOvens.org, “is a fuel used in the steelmaking process that is created by heating coal in the absence of air.” It heats pulverized coal to high temperatures over a long period. The process is called “thermal distillation.” Typically, it is heated for 15 to 18 hours but can take as long as 36 hours with temperatures normally between 1,650 and 2,000 degrees, the organization said. Several helicopters were at the scene as a mass casualty event was declared. Smoke can be seen billowing from the plant in a photo posted to social media by WPXI. BREAKING NEWS: A mass casualty incident has been declared to allow for additional EMS resources from across the region to respond. Check back for more on this developing story. ©2025 Cox Media Group
publish_date: August 11, 2025 at 8:30 am PDT August 11, 2025 at 8:30 am PDT

title: Current Weather Game Center 3 dead, 1 injured in North Austin Target shooting, suspect detained after car hijackings
content: Sunny 82 83 65 Today 83 65 Tuesday 89 63 Wednesday 75 60 Latest Weathercast Now 82 Tue 89 Wed 75 The Austin Police Department is actively investigating a shooting at the North Austin Target store that left three people dead. Be prepared for a few days of hot weather, with a Heat Advisory in effect for most of western Washington through Tuesday evening. Armstrong Williams takes on the news of the week and asks the questions you want answered. Don’t miss our weekly town hall by Stephanie Becerra TOPICS: AUSTIN, Texas — The Austin Police Department is actively investigating a shooting at the North Austin Target store that left three people dead and one other injured on Monday. A suspect is in custody, police said. During a media briefing, police said the 911 call came in at 2:15 p.m. reporting a shooting, and officers arrived by 2:19 p.m. to find three people were shot inside the parking lot at the Target located at 8601 Research Boulevard. Austin-Travis County EMS arrived at 2:23 p.m. and confirmed two of those people were pronounced dead on scene, and a third victim was pronounced dead at the hospital. One additional individual was treated on scene for unrelated injuries. The Austin Fire Department and Austin ISD Police also responded to the scene. According to the preliminary investigation, the suspect fled the store and allegedly hijacked a vehicle in the parking lot. Officers believe one of the victims was the driver of that stolen vehicle. The suspect then took that car and crashed it about 1.5 miles away in an officer complex parking lot at MoPac and Anderson Lane, according to APD. The suspect then reportedly hijacked another vehicle at a Volkswagen dealership and headed to South Austin. Shortly thereafter, APD officers responded to a 911 call for service at the 2400 block of La Costa Ct., where they located the suspect, tased him, and took him into custody at around 3:34 p.m. Police say the suspect is a 32-year-old White male who has a history of mental illness and a criminal record. "This is a very sad day for Austin. It's a very sad day for us all, and my condolences go out to the families," said Police Chief Lisa Davis during the media briefing. Police have shut down the 8000 block of MoPac southbound frontage road between Executive Center Drive and Anderson Lane. Police are letting out Target customers and staff who weren't witnesses to the incident, but say all the parked vehicles will have to stay until investigators are done with the scene. The scene is still active, and the investigation is ongoing. This developing story will be updated as more information becomes available.

title: Current Weather Game Center Man flees on foot after trying to rob Little Creek Casino with handgun
content: Sunny 68 84 64 Today 84 64 Tuesday 89 62 Wednesday 73 58 Latest Weathercast Now 68 Tue 89 Wed 73 The Austin Police Department is actively investigating a shooting at the North Austin Target store that left three people dead. Be prepared for a few days of hot weather, with a Heat Advisory in effect for most of western Washington through Tuesday evening. Armstrong Williams takes on the news of the week and asks the questions you want answered. Don’t miss our weekly town hall by KOMO News Staff TOPICS: MASON COUNTY, Wash. — The Mason County Sheriff's Office is asking for the public's help in identifying a suspect involved in an armed robbery at Little Creek Casino. The incident occurred on Aug. 9, at around 11:24 a.m. when a suspect entered the casino's supervisor station, brandished a handgun, and demanded money. Upon being informed that there was no money in the till, the suspect fled on foot. Patrol and K-9 units searched the area but were unable to find the suspect. He was last seen running toward Highway 101, then onto the overpass before disappearing from sight. The suspect is described as a possibly Hispanic male, aged between 20 and 30 years, approximately 5 feet 7 inches tall, with a small build. At the time of the robbery, he was wearing a gray or dark flannel button-up shirt, dark gray pants, dark "Romeo" style boots, a light gray hat with a white Nike logo, and sunglasses. Notably, he had a clear plastic glove on his right hand and was armed with a pistol. Authorities urge anyone with information about the suspect to call 911.

title: Current Weather Game Center Fall-like weather may soon return to Washington after a quick warmup
content: Sunny 84 83 63 Today 83 63 Monday 84 63 Tuesday 88 61 Latest Weathercast Now 84 Mon 84 Tue 88 The Austin Police Department is actively investigating a shooting at the North Austin Target store that left three people dead. Be prepared for a few days of hot weather, with a Heat Advisory in effect for most of western Washington through Tuesday evening. Armstrong Williams takes on the news of the week and asks the questions you want answered. Don’t miss our weekly town hall by Theron Zahn TOPICS: SEATTLE — Summer is about to remind us it is still in full swing... but that reminder won't last very long, according to recent data. Another heat wave is right around the corner, with forecasts calling for temps in the 90s in parts of southwest and eastern Washington starting as soon as Sunday. The newest drought monitor map from NOAA shows all of western Washington in at least a moderate drought, with some areas in severe drought and others in extreme drought. The driest areas are in the central to north Cascades, which means any new wildfire that starts could spread quickly. What comes next? According to government forecasters, western Washington can expect a 33 to 40 percent chance of below-normal temperatures over the next 8 to 14 days. When it comes to rainfall, NOAA says you can expect up to a 40 percent chance of above-normal precipitation. This means that after a brief heat snap, there is a good chance the fall-like weather we’ve seen in the last week could return soon.

title: Current Weather Game Center Paddleboarder discovers body floating in Duwamish River near yacht club
content: Sunny 82 85 64 Today 85 64 Monday 85 64 Tuesday 89 62 Latest Weathercast Now 82 Mon 85 Tue 89 The Austin Police Department is actively investigating a shooting at the North Austin Target store that left three people dead. Be prepared for a few days of hot weather, with a Heat Advisory in effect for most of western Washington through Tuesday evening. Armstrong Williams takes on the news of the week and asks the questions you want answered. Don’t miss our weekly town hall by KOMO News Staff TOPICS: DUWAMISH RIVER, Wash. — A paddleboarder made a grim discovery on the Duwamish River near the Duwamish Yacht Club on Sunday evening, prompting an investigation by local authorities. At around 5:25 p.m., the King County Sheriff's Office (KCSO) received a 911 call from a paddleboarder reporting that they had found what appeared to be a human body in the river. Deputies and local medics arrived at the scene and confirmed the presence of a dead person in the water. The KCSO Marine Unit was dispatched to document the scene and recover the body. The King County Medical Examiner’s Office has taken possession of the body and will work to determine the cause and manner of death. In accordance with protocol, the Marine Unit will collaborate with the KCSO Major Crimes Unit, the KCSO Missing Persons Coordinator, and the King County Medical Examiner’s Office to identify the deceased. As of now, the gender and approximate age of the person have not been determined or released. The circumstances surrounding how the person ended up in the water remain under investigation as authorities work to establish the person's identity.

title: Current Weather Game Center Spokane County Sheriff's Office sergeant hit and killed by motorcylist on I-90
content: Sunny 84 83 63 Today 83 63 Monday 84 63 Tuesday 88 61 Latest Weathercast Now 84 Mon 84 Tue 88 The Austin Police Department is actively investigating a shooting at the North Austin Target store that left three people dead. Be prepared for a few days of hot weather, with a Heat Advisory in effect for most of western Washington through Tuesday evening. Armstrong Williams takes on the news of the week and asks the questions you want answered. Don’t miss our weekly town hall by KOMO News Staff TOPICS: SPOKANE, Wash. — The Spokane County Sheriff's Office has announced that a sergeant was killed in the line of duty while helping with a traffic hazard on Saturday morning. Sergeant Kenneth Salas, 59, was struck by a motorcycle while assisting with clearing a lane on eastbound I-90 near the Four Lakes exit at approximately 7:40 a.m. According to a press memo, a circular hay bale fell off a vehicle near milepost 270 and came to rest in the left lane. Salas stopped his patrol car in the lane, with emergency lights and directional bar activated, and began clearing the hay. An approaching motorcyclist failed to observe the emergency lights, striking the patrol car and then Salas, killing him. The motorcyclist was injured in the crash and was taken to a local hospital. The SCSO said Sergeant Salas began his 34-year law enforcement career as a Spokane County Corrections Officer before joining the Sheriff's Office as a Patrol Deputy. Over the years, he served in various roles, including Patrol, School Resource Deputy, Traffic Unit, and the Emergency Operations Team. In 2004, he was promoted to Detective/Corporal, and in 2009, he became a Sergeant, serving as the Downtown Dayshift Patrol Sergeant Supervisor. Prior to his career with the SCSO, Salas served in the Air Force for over two decades. The Sheriff's Office described Sergeant Salas as "a valued and cherished member of our law enforcement family." He is survived by his wife and extended family. The Washington State Patrol is currently investigating the incident.

title: Current Weather Game Center Thurston County driver's preliminary breath test was 5 times the legal limit
content: Sunny 77 85 66 Today 85 66 Tuesday 90 63 Wednesday 75 59 Latest Weathercast Now 77 Tue 90 Wed 75 The Austin Police Department is actively investigating a shooting at the North Austin Target store that left three people dead. Be prepared for a few days of hot weather, with a Heat Advisory in effect for most of western Washington through Tuesday evening. Armstrong Williams takes on the news of the week and asks the questions you want answered. Don’t miss our weekly town hall Colleen West ,KOMONews TOPICS: THURSTON COUNTY, Wash. — Thurston County deputies and the sheriff were busy over the weekend when four drivers were arrested for suspicion of DUI in one night. The first arrest was made when a Thurston County Sheriff’s Office (TCSO) DUI enforcement deputy stopped a car near Pacific Avenue and Marvin Road for crossing over the fog line along the edge of the road. The driver also used both lanes to navigate the roundabout, according to the deputy. ALSO SEE | Cannabis sales in Washington fall for 5th year amid oversupply and declining prices The driver’s preliminary blood test (PBT) was 0.127%, according to the TCSO. The legal limit in Washington is 0.08%. The second driver to be arrested had an even higher PBT. In that case, a TCSO sergeant stopped a driver with a suspended license. The driver showed signs of being impaired and had a PBT of 0.390 – five times the legal limit. According to the National Institute on Alcohol Abuse and Alcoholism, someone with a blood alcohol concentration of 0.31 to 0.45 is in danger of an overdose and has a significant risk of dying. The driver was placed into custody and taken to the hospital until their blood alcohol level came down to a level safe enough to book them into jail. The third arrest came after a truck crashed in the Wendy’s drive-through lane and TCSO deputies were assisting Tumwater officers. Two people were sleeping in the vehicle, and what was believed to be a rifle, but was later found to be a pellet gun, was also in the truck along with a large amount of drug paraphernalia. The driver was arrested for investigation of DUI. The fourth driver was arrested by TCSO Sheriff Derek Sanders, who said he tried to stop a car on Martin Way after seeing the driver head the wrong way down the road, speed off, then slow down to 27 mph while swerving in and out of the lane. When Sanders tried to make a traffic stop, the driver refused to pull over, and Sanders and deputies boxed the vehicle in to bring it to a halt. Sanders said an 18-pack of beer was seen in the back seat and two empty beer cans were in the front of the car. The driver failed sobriety tests and was arrested for investigation of DUI. “Great work by all of our law enforcement to get these drivers off the roadway,” Sanders said on his Facebook page.

title: Current Weather Game Center Judge issues no-bail hold on man accused of shooting 2 people in Tacoma hospital ER
content: Sunny 80 85 64 Today 85 64 Tuesday 89 62 Wednesday 74 59 Latest Weathercast Now 80 Tue 89 Wed 74 The Austin Police Department is actively investigating a shooting at the North Austin Target store that left three people dead. Be prepared for a few days of hot weather, with a Heat Advisory in effect for most of western Washington through Tuesday evening. Armstrong Williams takes on the news of the week and asks the questions you want answered. Don’t miss our weekly town hall by KOMO News Staff The suspect, identified as Martice Ryan, is facing charges of murder in the first degree and assault in the first degree for the Aug. 6 incident. (KOMO) TOPICS: TACOMA, Wash. — A 25-year-old man accused of shooting two people in a Tacoma hospital emergency room, killing one man and injuring a woman, appeared in court on Monday. The suspect, identified as Martice Ryan, is facing charges of murder in the first degree and assault in the first degree for the Aug. 6 incident. PREVIOUS COVERAGE | 'That’s unbelievable': Latest on investigation of shooting at Tacoma hospital During the hearing, Ryan entered a plea of not guilty. The state requested a bail of $1.5 million, on the grounds of the violent nature of the crime and that the suspect was allegedly trying to flee the county when he was caught. Ryan was arrested on Aug. 8 after a multi-agency search in several counties. According to the prosecutor, Ryan does not have a criminal history, but does have 6 recorded law enforcement incidents where he was listed as a suspect in a crime. The judge ultimately issued a no-bail hold on Ryan. The Aug. 6 attack unfolded at the MultiCare Allenmore Hospital just after 7 p.m., where the victims were shot inside the emergency room. The male victim was pronounced dead at the scene, while the female victim was reported to be in stable condition. Investigators believed the shooter and the victims had an altercation before arriving at the hospital. "We don’t believe the moment was random," said Officer Shelbie Boyd, a spokesperson for the Tacoma Police Department. "We don’t know the relationship before the events of yesterday. Did they know each other before? We don’t know that." However, in the probable cause document, the surviving female victim told investigators that she and the male victim were sitting in the emergency room when Ryan approached them. According to the woman, Ryan asked the male victim if he knew Ryan, and the male victim said he did not. Ryan then allegedly opened fire on the duo, killing the man and wounding the woman. The woman told police she did not recognize Ryan, and stated multiple times there was no prior interaction between the male victim and Ryan before arriving at the hospital. Access to the hospital was restricted following the shooting, but operations resumed as normal on Thursday. The community around Allenmore Hospital expressed shock at the incident. "That's unbelievable - how is there a shooting in the hospital?" said Lindsey Ross, a local resident. "I would think it would be safe, but it’s not."

title: Current Weather Game Center Venus and Jupiter appear close in the sky as summer's best meteor shower peaks soon
content: Sunny 82 83 65 Today 83 65 Tuesday 89 63 Wednesday 75 60 Latest Weathercast Now 82 Tue 89 Wed 75 The Austin Police Department is actively investigating a shooting at the North Austin Target store that left three people dead. Be prepared for a few days of hot weather, with a Heat Advisory in effect for most of western Washington through Tuesday evening. Armstrong Williams takes on the news of the week and asks the questions you want answered. Don’t miss our weekly town hall by Christina Larson | AP Science Writer TOPICS: WASHINGTON — Summer's most dazzling meteor shower, the Perseids, peaks early Wednesday. At the same time, Venus and Jupiter will converge in the sky — overlapping like a very bright star. If your focus is the meteor shower, it's worth knowing that this year a bright moon will dampen viewing during the pre-dawn peak, so some experts recommend waiting a week or so to glimpse shooting stars against a darker sky. The Perseids "are an incredible meteor shower,” said Thaddeus LaCoursiere, planetarium program coordinator at the Bell Museum in St. Paul, Minnesota. Under dark skies with no moon, the Perseids can produce between 60 to 100 meteors per hour, he said. Since the moon will be around 84% full during the peak, skywatchers might expect between 10 to 20 meteors per hour, according to the American Meteor Society. “This year I’m actually recommending that people go out a little bit later" — a week or so past the peak when the moon will not be as bright, LaCoursiere said. Viewing of the Perseids lasts until August 23. As the Earth orbits the sun, several times a year it passes through debris left by passing comets and sometimes asteroids. The source of the Perseids is debris from comet 109P/Swift-Tuttle. When these fast-moving space rocks enter Earth’s atmosphere, the debris encounters new resistance from the air and becomes very hot, eventually burning up. Sometimes the surrounding air glows briefly, leaving behind a fiery tail — the end of a “shooting star.” You don’t need special equipment to see the various meteor showers that flash across annually, just a spot away from city lights. The best time to watch a meteor shower is in the early predawn hours when the moon is low in the sky. Competing sources of light — such as a bright moon or artificial glow — are the main obstacles to a clear view of meteors. Cloudless nights when the moon wanes smallest are optimal viewing opportunities. And keep looking up, not down. Your eyes will be better adapted to spot shooting stars if you aren’t checking your phone. The next major meteor shower, the Orionids, peaks in late October.

title: Current Weather Game Center Know the signs of heat stroke, exhaustion and what to do next
content: Sunny 81 84 65 Today 84 65 Tuesday 89 63 Wednesday 75 60 Latest Weathercast Now 81 Tue 89 Wed 75 The Austin Police Department is actively investigating a shooting at the North Austin Target store that left three people dead. Be prepared for a few days of hot weather, with a Heat Advisory in effect for most of western Washington through Tuesday evening. Armstrong Williams takes on the news of the week and asks the questions you want answered. Don’t miss our weekly town hall by KOMO News Staff TOPICS: SEATTLE — Temperatures are heating up across western Washington with highs in the mid-90s expected in parts of the region this week and many areas under a Heat Advisory. The Pacific Northwest is no stranger to heat waves, but with many buildings not having air conditioning, it's always a struggle to keep cool when the mid-summer heat arrives. CLICK HERE FOR YOUR LATEST KOMO NEWS FORECAST Older adults, young children, and people with mental illness and chronic diseases are at highest risk for heat-related illness, according to the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC). But even young, healthy people can suffer in heat, especially if they participate in physical activities. The first step to avoid heat-related illnesses is to know the signs of them coming on and what to do next. If someone is experiencing heat stroke, call 911 right away and move the person to a cooler place. You can help lower the person's temperature with cool cloths or a cool bath. You should not give the person anything to drink. People experiencing heat exhaustion should be moved to a cool place, hydrate, and reduce their temperature with cool clothes or a cool bath. People should seek medical help if symptoms worsen or last longer than one hour. For more information about heat-related illnesses, visit the CDC's website. RELATED: Here's how to keep your pets safe during a heat wave Besides avoiding heat illnesses, there are several other key ways to stay safe and survive the heat wave. Libraries are often open to help people beat the heat, check their individual websites for more information: Seattle, Tacoma, Everett, Bellevue, Kent, and Renton. Stay with KOMO News for the latest on your forecast here. Follow us on Facebook, X (Twitter), Instagram, and TikTok. Subscribe to our YouTube channel.

title: Motorcyclist critically injured in crash; driver with active warrant arrested for vehicular assault
content: SEATTLE — A motorcyclist was critically injured following a collision in Seattle’s Greenwood neighborhood Saturday morning. Just before noon on Saturday, August 9, officers responded to a collision involving a motorcycle and a car near North 85th Street and Linden Avenue North. According to the Seattle Police Department (SPD), officers arrived to find a 33-year-old man critically injured in the roadway and a 27-year-old man sitting nearby. Firefighters took the motorcyclist to Harborview Medical Center with life-threatening injuries. Detectives say an investigation revealed a red Ford was traveling westbound on North 85th Street when it attempted a U-turn to head eastbound. As the SUV turned, the motorcyclist, who was traveling behind the SUV, changed lanes to pass and collided with the car. A Drug Recognition Expert evaluated the driver of the SUV and determined he was impaired. Officers then learned the driver had a suspended license, no insurance, and an active warrant for assault. He was booked into King County Jail for investigation of vehicular assault. The investigation remains open and ongoing. Anyone with information is asked to call the Traffic Collision Investigation Squad at 206-684-8923. ©2025 Cox Media Group

title: Over 7,000 Chinook salmon expected to return to Whatcom Creek
content: BELLINGHAM, Wash. — The Washington Department of Fish and Wildlife (WDFW) says they are anticipating the largest Chinook Salmon return on record in Bellingham. In a collaborative effort between WDFW, Bellingham Technical College (BTC), Northwest Indian Fisheries Commission (NWIFC), and the Lummi Nation and Nooksack Indian Tribe, more than 7,000 Chinook are expected to return to the Whatcom Creek. “We have been working collectively and diligently to bring back salmon for all of our tribal people, as well as all Washington state residents and our future generations,” said Lisa Wilson, vice chair of the Northwest Indian Fisheries Commission and a member of Lummi Nation leadership. “We created a 10-year, co-managed hatchery plan for these Chinook and we are now seeing the results of this hard work.” The salmon are raised in the Samish Hatchery, run by the Washington Department of Fish and Wildlife. When the fish are big enough to survive on their own, they are released where Whatcom Creek meets Bellingham Bay, a WDFW release said. The Chinook are raised to increase food for orcas, support tribal fishing, and teach students how to raise salmon in a hatchery. ©2025 Cox Media Group

title: Carjackers take big rig, lead police on chase through Los Angeles
content: LOS ANGELES — For a city known for stunt drivers speeding through the streets, a high-speed chase may have looked like it was being shot for a movie. But the chase through the streets of Los Angeles was anything but fiction. Sheriff’s deputies are looking for two armed people who carjacked several vehicles on Aug. 10, including a big rig, KABC reported. The chase was broadcast live, KTTV reported. The pair allegedly carjacked a pickup truck. When the driver of the pickup followed them in another vehicle, one of the suspects shot at him, KNBC reported. No one was hurt, the Los Angeles County Sheriff’s Department said. That’s when the police pursuit began, with at least one of the alleged carjackers firing at officers after they drove in the wrong direction on the freeway. At one point, the driver of the pickup got out of that truck and jumped into the cab of a tanker truck. Police then chased the tanker truck on the 5 Freeway, KTTV reported. KABC reported it was not hauling a hazardous load, instead possibly a milk truck. After about a 30-minute freeway chase changed location with the driver taking the tanker off the highway and right into downtown Los Angeles’ surface streets. It slowed as the chase went around high-rise buildings. Eventually, the tanker truck’s driver took the rig back on the 10 Freeway, going the wrong way, directly into oncoming traffic. Eventually, the pair got out of the tanker and allegedly took a third vehicle, a white pickup truck, leading police on another chase. At one point, the driver and passenger swapped places, continuing the pursuit until they stopped, carjacking a fourth vehicle. That’s when law enforcement lost sight of them, KABC reported. © 2025 Cox Media Group
publish_date: August 11, 2025 at 11:44 am PDT August 11, 2025 at 11:44 am PDT

title: Current Weather Game Center Raleigh hits MLB-leading 45th homer as the Mariners beat the Rays 6-3 for 7th straight win
content: Clear 68 86 65 Today 86 65 Monday 86 65 Tuesday 90 63 Latest Weathercast Now 68 Mon 86 Tue 90 The Austin Police Department is actively investigating a shooting at the North Austin Target store that left three people dead. Be prepared for a few days of hot weather, with a Heat Advisory in effect for most of western Washington through Tuesday evening. by ASSOCIATED PRESS TOPICS: SEATTLE — Cal Raleigh hit his major league-leading 45th home run in a four-run first inning and the Seattle Mariners hung on for a 6-3 victory over the Tampa Bay Rays on Sunday. It was Seattle’s seventh straight win, the longest active run in the American League. Josh Naylor also homered for the Mariners, who wrapped up a 9-1 homestand. PREVIOUSLY | Raleigh crushes MLB-best 44th homer and Rodríguez hits 2 as streaking Mariners top Rays Seattle starter Bryan Woo (10-6) allowed three runs on seven hits over six innings with nine strikeouts. It was his 23rd start this season of six innings or more. Raleigh’s two-run home run came off Rays starter Adrian Houser before Eugenio Suarez added a two-run single for the Mariners in the first. Raleigh, who homered in all three games of the seriers, hit No. 44, a three-run shot, in the third inning of the Mariners’ 7-4 victory over the Rays on Saturday. The Rays chipped away at Seattle’s lead. Ha-Seong Kim’s double in the second scored Brandon Lowe to close the gap. Yandy Diaz added an RBI grounder in the third. Kim hit a solo homer in the fourth to make it 4-3. Naylor gave the Mariners some breathing room with a solo homer in the seventh. Dominic Canzone had an RBI single in the eighth for the final margin. Hauser (6-4) allowed four runs on six hits over five innings with four strikeouts and three walks. Key moment Julio Rodríguez got hit on the elbow by a 97-mph fastball from Adrian Houser in the fourth inning. When he took his elbow guard off to take first, he paused to kiss it. Key stat Raleigh moved into a tie with Johnny Bench (1970) at second all-time for most homers by a catcher in a season. Salvador Perez had 48 in 2021. Up next The Rays head to Sacramento, California, to face the Athletics on Monday. The Rays did not announce a starter against A’s LHP Jeffrey Springs (10-7, 3.89 ERA). The Mariners visit the Baltimore Orioles on Tuesday. RHP George Kirby (7-5, 4.04) will start for Seattle against RHP Dean Kremer (8-8, 4.35).

title: PinPoint Alert: Today and tomorrow for widespread upper-80s and lower-90s
content: A PinPoint Alert is in effect for western Washington today and tomorrow because of very hot temps. There is a Heat Advisory for most of the area, except the coast and a few places from Island County north into San Juan County. We had temps yesterday in the upper-80s in Seattle and upper-80s to low-90s around Tacoma south. We’ll warm a couple of degrees today with highs in the upper-80s to mid-90s. Seattle should hit 90°, same with Tacoma and Bremerton. We’ll be in the low to mid-90s around Olympia to Chehalis. Everett will be in the upper-80s along with Bellingham. Even with those hot temps today, we will more than likely not set records today. Most records are just too high for us today. Tomorrow, cooler ocean air will move into the coast, but should hold off inland. That means our temps inland could warm another couple of degrees or be at least just as hot if the ocean air influences us a little. The record for today and tomorrow in Seattle is 96°, and I’m staying below that both days. Olympia’s record for today is 100°, but tomorrow the record is 96°, and we’ll be right around that. The cooler ocean air will come inland Tuesday night with widespread low clouds on Wednesday morning. Our highs will drop a ton with temps only in the low to mid-70s with some afternoon sun. Thursday looks mostly cloudy but still dry; however, rain is coming on Friday with highs in the upper-60s only! The weekend will be slightly warmer, but we’ll have a few lingering showers early on Saturday with mainly dry afternoon conditions. Highs will be in the low to mid-70s. Air quality looks good to possibly moderate for most of the area, but we will have reduced air quality around Mason County and the south end of the Hood Canal. Cooling Center According to Sound Transit, Union Station will be extending its Great Hall hours for cooling for the next few days from 7 a.m. to 7 p.m. – until the heat advisory expires. List of 90 degree plus days in Seattle in 10 year increments:1946-55 81956-65 311966-75 311976-85 281986-95 401996-2005 162006-15 492016-25 67 ( so far )Chance for 2 more today and Tuesday before the 70s come back Wednesday. #wawx ©2025 Cox Media Group

title: Current Weather Game Center Man released after wrongful arrest in Wallingford fatal house fire case
content: Sunny 84 83 63 Today 83 63 Tuesday 89 62 Wednesday 74 58 Latest Weathercast Now 84 Tue 89 Wed 74 Be prepared for a few days of hot weather, with a Heat Advisory in effect for most of western Washington through Tuesday evening. by Michelle Esteban, KOMO News Reporter TOPICS: SEATTLE — Sharp criticism has been directed at Seattle police and King County prosecutors following the dismissal of charges against Letian Shi, a Seattle man who was wrongfully arrested in connection with a deadly house fire in June. Shi was released from jail after spending nearly a month behind bars, as questions arose regarding his identification as the suspect. Shi's attorneys issued a statement condemning the investigation, saying, "Time and time again, police ignored exculpatory evidence that would have kept an innocent man from spending a month behind bars for no reason. Prosecutors should have—and could have—demanded a more thorough investigation before filing life-altering charges with the potential to jeopardize Mr. Shi’s employment and his right to remain lawfully in the country he now calls home." The statement further noted that the experience has deeply affected Shi, leaving him with a lack of trust in the criminal legal system and a fear of being unjustly taken from his community again. Initially, prosecutors linked Shi to the fatal fire that claimed the life of a 72-year-old Wallingford resident through surveillance video and a fast-food receipt. However, the defense argued that Shi was not the man identified on the surveillance footage, presenting side-by-side photos to support their claim. When asked about the dismissal, prosecutors stated that new information had emerged, leading them to question the suspect's identity. "The police investigations are ongoing," they said. "Prosecutors can act on the best information that we have from police at each time. And I think what we did here on Friday to make that motion to dismiss is what the public would expect when you have that new information." Seattle Police Department (SPD) confirmed in a police blotter post that they are still seeking the real suspect in the Wallingford fatal house fire, stating, "Earlier in the investigation, police arrested a potential suspect who appeared to match the description of a dark-haired man seen on camera footage. SPD detectives worked closely with prosecutors quickly to secure his release once new information emerged that showed the man was innocent." The real suspect remains at large, and the investigation continues.

title: Docs: Surviving victim of Tacoma ER shooting says suspected gunman was a stranger
content: TACOMA, Wash. — A man accused of killing one and injuring another in a shooting at a Tacoma emergency room was apparently a stranger to both victims, according to newly obtained court documents. The shooting happened on Aug. 6 around 7 p.m. inside the MultiCare Allenmore Hospital on South Union Ave. According to court documents, the couple arrived at the emergency room because one of them was experiencing elbow pain. When they checked in and sat in the waiting room, the surviving shooting victim said a man approached the pair and asked her boyfriend what he was staring at, docs said. The man replied he wasn’t staring, and the suspect asked him if he knew who he was. The victim said he did not, court documents said. According to court documents, the suspect said something along the lines of “it’s about to get switchy in here” before he started firing. Prosecutors say “switchy” likely refers to converting a semi-automatic handgun to a fully-automatic handgun. Both the man and the woman were shot. The man died at the scene and the woman was grazed by a bullet. The suspect, later identified as 25-year-old Martrice Ryan, ran away from the hospital. The surviving victim later told police that nothing happened during their drive to the hospital to indicate that they had been followed. Ryan was arrested and booked into the Pierce County Jail on Aug. 10. He has been charged with first-degree murder and first-degree assault. Prosecutors asked that he be held on no bail. ©2025 Cox Media Group
publish_date: August 11, 2025 at 5:59 pm PDT August 11, 2025 at 5:59 pm PDT

title: Vick’s Burger Shack in Sultan destroyed by fire
content: SULTAN, Wash. — A popular restaurant in Sultan is picking up the pieces after a fire destroyed the shop. Vick’s Burger Shack has been around for over a decade – and on August 9, around midnight, it went up in flames. “It was just devastating – couldn’t believe the amount of damage done. I think we’re mostly still in shock,” said Jennifer Vick, whose parents own the business. Vick says her brother, who lives right next door, suddenly saw flashing lights and smoke coming out of the shack. The flames destroyed just about everything inside, costing around $80,000 to $100,000 in damage. The cause of the fire is currently under investigation. Vick says it was likely an equipment malfunction and not arson, according to a fire marshal who said there will not be an investigation. Making matters even worse, Vick says her parents do not have insurance, even though they thought they did. They recently switched companies and after the fire, were told there was a clerical error – so no coverage. “They had messed up on billing and there wasn’t a policy. They didn’t notify us or anything,” said Vick. Vick has started an online fundraiser to help cover the costs of rebuilding. At last check, it has raised just over $15,000. “It would be real easy to be crying and not know where to go, but the community is really rallying and carrying us through this. We’re grateful for them,” said Vick. The family is now looking at possibly buying a food truck to start serving customers again. ©2025 Cox Media Group
publish_date: August 11, 2025 at 6:13 pm PDT August 11, 2025 at 6:13 pm PDT

title: Amazon
content: Our columnist's take on what to watch in a year that may not be like one we've seen in a long time. After feuds during Donald Trump’s first term, President-elect Trump and Amazon founder Jeff Bezos have both noted their recent evolving relationship. Workers at seven Amazon facilities are on strike. The suit appears to be the first wrongful-death suit to be brought against One Medical, which was acquired by Amazon in February 2023.

title: Overgrown brush and dry weather create wildfire concerns
content: BELLEVUE, Wash. — This hot, dry weather has firefighters concerned about the fire danger across the state. We have seen several fires on the west side of the mountains- including the stubborn Bear Gulch fire on Lake Cushman that remains just 3% contained. In Bellevue, crews say a fire over the weekend could have been catastrophic. And it is easy to see why: the burned trees have exposed the facade of the Wedgewood Condominiums. That building and the people inside were directly in harm’s way. “He start yelling, ‘fire, fire,” said Vladimir Kolderstov, remembering the moment when he was alerted. “’Get out. Get out.’ It was (a) police officer.” That was the first Koldertsov knew that the trees right behind the home he shares with his wife in the Wedgewood Condominiums were going up in flames. “It was awful,” he said. “It just was awful.” ‘Awful’ and, he says, he had warned management for years about the trees and overgrown vegetation. “It’s enough that one cigarette to initiate the fire,” said Kolderstov. That is now what Bellevue Fire suspects may have sparked this fire Saturday afternoon. “We do see each summer the season seems to get a little bit longer as far as the dry spell goes with it,” said Battalion Chief Keith Allen. And, according to the state Department of Natural Resources, even the forecast for rain later this week likely won’t douse the fire threat. “The fire can smolder in duff, that’s the organic material at the base of the trees comprised of sort of decomposing pine needles, twigs, branches, et cetera,” said Thomas Kyle-Milward, DNR. “And the fire can smolder in that material even with some rainfall and then flare up again as you see heat return.” These fires can spread so quickly. The people tell us embers from the fire jumped across 148th Avenue Northeast and landed on a bush, setting it on fire, too. Firefighters say the fire danger likely won’t end until the fall rains begin. ©2025 Cox Media Group
publish_date: August 11, 2025 at 9:19 pm PDT August 11, 2025 at 9:19 pm PDT

title: Deputies: Speeding, alcohol may have been a factor in Sultan deadly UTV crash
content: SULTAN, Wash. — A 46-year-old was killed after he lost control of his Utility Task Vehicle (UTV) and crashed it in Sultan over the weekend. The crash happened around 10:15 p.m. near Index-Galena Road and National Forest Road 6310. Deputies say the UTV’s driver was speeding over a hillcrest with a curve. That caused him to hit a guardrail, where he was thrown out of the vehicle. It does not appear the driver was strapped in. The driver was pronounced dead at the scene by Sky Valley Fire Department personnel. Detectives are still working to determine the cause of the crash, but speed and alcohol are believed to be contributing factors. ©2025 Cox Media Group
publish_date: August 11, 2025 at 7:09 pm PDT August 11, 2025 at 7:09 pm PDT
